Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding. Just an hour ago, I’d made a careless joke at lunch, and now I’d learned it had cut my friend deeply. I knew I needed to call her, to apologize, to explain myself and listen—because that’s what friends do. We don’t let misunderstandings fester. But as I reached for my phone, the convent’s bell rang urgently. Sister Maria rushed in, breathless, telling me the mayor was on the line. The hurricane had devastated the town, and he was pleading for our help to organize relief for the hundreds suddenly homeless. As a nun, I was expected to put the needs of the suffering first, to lead our sisters in service and charity. My friend’s pain tugged at my heart, but so did the cries of those left with nothing. I stood frozen, torn between the call of compassion for one and the desperate needs of many, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me, demanding I choose.
